titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1 V:30. A Sleepless Night. The cause of which I could not assign to myself, but it was with a dispersion of spirits which disabled me from turning to account the time thus cast upon me; towards the dawn, only I fixed my mind upon a train of thought suited to the occasion and rose just after daylight— Received a Note from the President, desiring the members of the Administration to meet at his house at 11. O’Clock— Mr Calhoun and Mr Wirt were there— The President had prepared answers for General Mason to return to both Mr Duponceau’s Letters— The substance of them was that he was sure the Government as well as People of the United States entertained the most friendly Sentiments; towards the People of Cuba, and felt the most lively interest in their welfare but that their relations with Spain, did not admit of their forming any engagements in the present state of things; such as were implied in the proposals of Mr Sanchez; and that the Executive Government would not in any event be competent to form them, without the concurrence of Congress. The more secret Letter suggested as General Mason’s own idea that it would be well for Mr Sanchez to give information more explicit and precise of the authority by which he acted; whence it came—who were the persons concerned in the project—how far it was matured, and what means and resources they had for accomplishing their purpose— I suggested the expediency, that General Mason should furnish copies, both of Mr Duponceau’s Letters and of the answers—to which the President said he would attend— Mr Wirt gave a written opinion in the case of the Danish Slave, which was that the President had the power to deliver him up. I asked him where he found the grant of the Power in the Constitution— He said it was in the general instruction to take care that the Laws should be faithfully executed. I said that in his opinion that the President could not deliver up a Pirate, he did not admit that doctrine—where did he find it now? He said, laughing, that he took it from me. But his opinion as to the mode in which the delivery is to be effected was altogether nugatory— It presumes that the President might order the Marshal to take the man and deliver him over to the Danish Minister without ceremony; but he recommends that the Governor of New-York should be written to, and invited, to deliver up the man— I said that I should ask to be excused from writing either the order to the Marshal, or the Letter to the Governor of New-York; for I was convinced that in the first case if the Marshal should obey the order, the man would be taken out of his custody by Habeas Corpus, and very probably he himself be presented in a State Court for False Imprisonment, by the manumission Society; and in the second we should have an answer from the Governor of New-York, not only refusing to deliver up the man but subjoining a commentary upon the demand, which would be any thing other than palatable. Mr Wirt said that the subject was quite as much political as legal; and he wished the President would take other opinions as well as his— The truth is that between his Virginian aversion to constructive powers, his Virginian devotion to State Rights, and his Virginian autocracy against Slaves, his two opinions form the most absurd jumble of self-contradictions that could be imagined— If the President has not the power to deliver up a Pirate, he cannot possibly have power to deliver up a Slave— Mr Calhoun agreed entirely with Mr Wirt as to the power of the President, in the case of fugitive Slaves, but felt more the difficulty of carrying it into execution. Calhoun has no petty scruples about constructive Powers, and State Rights— His opinions are at least consistent— I have no doubt that by the Constitution the President has the Power, but perhaps a Law of Congress may be necessary, providing the process, by which the power should be exercised. Despotism itself would be startled at Wirt’s opinion that the Marshal under a bare order from the
President through the Secretary of State, should have power to seize a man, without judge or jury, pack him on board ship, and send him out of the Country, like a bag of cotton. An invitation to the Governor of New-York to do the same thing is not less absurd. The President said he would take time to reflect upon the subject, before coming to his determination. He left the City for his seat in Albemarle County, immediately after the Meeting. Dr Thornton was at my house this Evening. I wrote a Letter to James Lloyd, and sent him a copy of my pamphlet.

2. VI: A good Night’s rest again restored me to my usual capacities of action. Mr H. Johnson the Senator from Louisiana came with three French Citizens of that State; General Plauché, Mr Fleitas, and Mr Prudhomme, whom he introduced to me— The General was in service, as Commander of the State Militia, at the attack upon New-Orleans, in 1815. a period to which he takes pleasure in recurring. Dr Thornton was at my house— I called at the Office of the Comptroller, Mr Anderson, with a Letter from General Rector, to the late Mr Meigs which has recently been found among his papers, and which Mrs Meigs has sent me. It was written in 1815. and expressly admits that charge of 300 dollars upon the Surveys of Land, had been by accident omitted from the credits of his general Account. This seemed to be the particular document that had been required at the Treasury for the final adjustment of Mr Meig’s account, and I left it with the Comptroller. He thought at first that it was a letter lately received, and said that Rector’s own Accounts had lately been quite irregular and made a voucher from him questionable, but observing it dated in 1815, he said it might perhaps answer. I told him I had been obliged to suspend the credit upon the public Bankers of London, of his nephew and namesake the Consul at Tripoli; from whom for nearly three years, neither Account nor Letter has been received, and who in the meantime has drawn to his utmost tether— He expressed much concern at hearing this, but approved of the measure. Stone the engraver brought me an impression of his fac-simile engraving of the Declaration of Independence— He has finished the signatures and they are well done; but upon the Declaration itself, he has yet much to labour— The day was stormy, and we had fire in the Dining-room: the first time for the Season— Evening at Chess with W. S. Smith.

3. VI: Change of Apparel from Summer to Winter Cloathing— And removed into my Audience chamber, at the Office, for some necessary repairs to the chimney piece of my Office Chamber— Applied to Latruite, Silversmith to make me a new Pen ring— An instrument from which I have for these six years derived the most useful Service, and without which it would have been almost impossible for me to write. I returned the visit of General Plauché and his companions, at Mrs Peyton’s, but did not see them. Wrote Letters to A. Gallatin, to C. A. Rodney, and to T. D. Arnold, with copies of my pamphlet; and a Letter to my Son Charles— From this Mr Arnold I received lately a Letter dated, Knoxville, Tennessee, asking for a copy of my Book— The writer is unknown to me; but he professes honest feelings, and I have no reason for disbelieving him— Dr Thornton called at the Office, with a proposal to borrow money, which I declined— Evening at Chess— Received a Letter from my wife, with her journal to the 1st. instt. inclusive— She had the day before returned to Philadelphia, after a visit of a fortnight at Mr Hopkinson’s at Bordentown, which she has passed very agreeably. She has also received many attentions during that time from Joseph Buonaparte, otherwise called the Count de Survilliers, and his daughter, who are residing in the immediate neighbourhood of Mr Hopkinson’s house.

4. VI: I received this morning a Note from C. J. Burckle, a German, a Citizen of the United States, sometime resident at Philadelphia, stating that he had just arrived from Bogota, the Capital of the Republic of Colombia, charged with a mercantile negotiation very important for the new Republic and interesting to the United States— And requesting an interview with me— I answered that I would
receive him immediately and he came— He said he was authorised to negotiate here or in Europe a Loan of three Millions of Dollars for the Government of the Republic of Colombia, upon terms very advantageous to the lenders, and which if successful would be of great benefit to the commercial violations of the United States—A great part of the money being wanted to pay for supplies which may be obtained in this Country, but which if the loan should be made in Europe, would be sought there. The project included, an exclusive privilege for exporting certain Articles during a number of years, and appeared to be the same as that in which Dr Bollmann was engaged when he died some months since at Jamaica, on his way to England. Mr Burckle shewed me his authority which appeared to be regular and complete; originally given to a person named B. Elbers, with substitution by him to Burckle, and all authenticated, by the Vice-President of the Republic Santander. Burckle’s enquiry was whether this Government would be disposed to countenance this loan, by private communication to persons in Philadelphia, who might incline to engage in it, such as Stephen Girard, Robert Ralston, or the United States Bank, intimating the President’s opinion, or mine, that the borrowers deserve Confidence— I told him that the President being absent, I could only refer the subject to him, and answer according to such directions as he should give. He said he must proceed immediately to Philadelphia, and unless he should succeed there, within a few weeks to Europe— I promised to write to the President immediately, and did in the course of the day. Burckle told me that Mr Gebhard the member of Congress from New-York State was his brother-in-Law and that he was also related to one of the members from Pennsylvania— I had some conversation with him on the general subject of the affairs of the Republic of Colombia, and of Mexico. Burckle had written Letters from Bogota to R. Ralston exceedingly unfavourable to the Country and its Rulers, which Letters Ralston had sent me. I intimated to him that I had seen them, and he was conscious of their contents— He said there had been great changes there since those Letters were written, and things had acquired much greater stability, since the new organization of the Government. He added however that the People were altogether different there from ours; less enlightened; more immoral, and could not be governed in the same manner. Yet they were decidedly partial to a Republican form of Government; were much dissatisfied with the Imperial dignity assumed by Yturbide in Mexico; and very much afraid of him.— They disliked San Martin for his affectations of Protectoral power in Peru, and they had a better opinion of Bolivar himself, for a General, than for a Liberator President. He spoke of Mr Ravenga, who was going to be the Minister of the Colombian Republic in England, but who after embarking, had by some accident happening to the sloop in which he had sailed, been obliged to return. He gave me a Newspaper, containing a declaration from the Government that Mr Zea was the only person in Europe authorised to contract for them; for it seems others have pretended to such authority, and brought upon them burdensome bargains— He also offered, and afterwards sent me a file of Bogota Newspapers to the 25th. of August— At the Office there came a Mr L. Chastant, and L. D. Shewell— Received a Letter from my wife, enclosing one for Mr Thomas Cook, which I took to him this Evening at his house— After returning I wrote an answer to Asbury Dickins’s Letter notifying to me, my Election as President of the Columbian Institute— Chess with W. S. Smith.

5. V:15.Mr Daniel Brent called this morning at my house, being now just recovered from a severe bilious fever with which he has been nearly a month confined at his house in the Country. He
told me that Mr John Law died last Night— Also of a bilious fever— It was but so lately that he was telling me full of life and hilarity, of the parting banquet with the Players— Death should be a greater teacher Yet how little do we learn from him— John Law was one of the most elegant, & cultivated minds, among the inhabitants of this district, and will be a great loss to them. He had litterature and taste— And they had not been in him, as sometimes happens extinguished by the practice of the Law— Mr G. W. Erving called, on his return from visiting Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison in Virginia— He is going shortly to Philadelphia— He gave me his opinion of the late Lord Londonderry of the Baron de Neuville and of the Chevalier de Onis, not altogether concurring with mine. I think better of the two former than he does— It is not easy to estimate accurately the moral character of Public men— Their reputation is always made up, of a composition by friends and foes; all discoloured by favour and by hatred. There is a disposition to believe rather the ill than the good that is said of them; virtue is never presumed, and seldom credited, by or in political adversaries— Dr Tucker, the Treasurer came and introduced to me a young man named Berald, belonging to Norfolk Virginia, who has been attending the Law Lectures at Harvard University— Mr H. Johnson the Senator from Louisiana, brought and introduced a Mr Labranche a French Citizen of Louisiana; his Son, another Louisianian, and a Mr Suter from Charleston South-Carolina— Labranche is a native of Louisiana, and has just returned from a visit to France— At the Office I received a despatch from Mr Gallatin with a copy of a long Letter from him to R. Rush, upon the new Fishery question, raised by the pretensions of the French to exclusive right of fishing on the western Coast of Newfoundland— There was a meeting of the Columbian Institute this afternoon, but I was prevented from attending it, by the funeral of Mr Law— I rode to the house, with Mr Richard Forrest; and thence to the grave-yard with Mr Calhoun— The service at the grave was performed by Mr Little— Mr Calhoun also brought me home— We had some conversation upon the quarrel, between Coll. Cumming of Georgia, and Mr M’Duffie the member of Congress from South-Carolina; Calhoun’s protegé, friend and partizan— This feud has become a sort of historical incident. It originated in the rivalry between Crawford and Calhoun for the Presidential succession— Began by some vulgar abuse upon each other in newspapers, in consequence of which Cumming challenged M’Duffie before the last Session of Congress; and came here last winter during the Session to fight him— The meeting was then postponed to 30 days after the close of the Session of Congress, when they met and M’Duffie was shot in the back— They then returned to the war, of newspaper ribaldry, till Cumming challenged him a second time. By double manoeuvering on both sides about the time place and circumstances of meeting the second duel was avoided, and each party resorted again to hand-bills, posting, newspaper proclamations of of imputed cowardice, and pamphleteering— The seconds, Surgeons and Others have got involved in the dispute, and all have become the laughing Stock of the public throughout the Union, except in South-Carolina and Georgia; where the parties are feasted and toasted, “alive or dead.” Never was such a burlesque upon duels since the practice existed. Both parties were considered as unerring shots, and there was before they fought made such ludicrous lamentation, in the presage that they would both be killed. From the contradictory statements of both parties it appears that it has been on the part of Cumming a deliberate and determined purpose of assassination founded on a confidence in his own shooting, joined to a belief of M’Duffie’s want of nerve to meet the occasion, without disabling trepidation— And on the part of M’Duffie, a faltering resolution, shrinking both from the fight, and the refusal to fight— Dragged into the field against his will, and without just cause—behaving equivocally upon it; making and snatching at pretences to withdraw from it, boasting of his own firmness against the evidence of facts, and covering his
retreat by charging cowardice upon his antagonist. Calhoun, does not talk of it with pleasure: but says Cumming is subject to hereditary insanity from his mother— He told me that General Jackson would certainly come to the next Congress, in the place of N. Cannon— Mr Frye was at my house this Evening; and I walked home with him— Chess with Smith.

6. VI:30. I wasted my time this morning—“On our firm resolves, the inaudible and noiseless foot of Time steals”—how often! Heard Mr Little; in the forenoon from 2. Corinthians 5.10. [“]For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ; that every one may receive the things done in his body according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad.” Upon the immortality of the Soul, and a future State of rewards and punishments— The fundamental and all import doctrine of Christianity, and the only sanction of morals against the principles of selfishness and expediency. Mr Little gave notice that he should next Sunday preach a funeral Sermon, upon the decease of Mr John Law— After the morning Service, I called at Strothers to return the visits of Mr Labranche and his companions, but they were gone. Met Mr George Hay with General Scott just returned from Philadelphia— The afternoon Sermon was from Luke 7.16. “And there came a fear on all: and they glorified God, saying, that a great prophet is risen among us; and that God hath visited his people.” This was an Unitarian Sermon. Johnson Hellen left us and returned to Rockville. He has barely recovered from his fever, and I urged him to stay longer with us; but he was anxious to return, as the elections in Maryland for Congress, and for the State Legislature, are to be held to-morrow— This Evening I wrote to my wife, and gave her my reasons for declining to go and pass a week at Philadelphia, as urged in one of her last Letters.

7. V:15. At the Office Dr. Ayres of Baltimore came with Letters from Mr Wirt the Attorney General and Mr Homans, the Chief Clerk of the Navy Department— The object of Dr. Ayres is the effectual prosecution of Captain Chase, the piratical privateersman, who brought into Baltimore under the flag of the Republic of Colombia, fourteen African Negroes, whom he captured at Sea, and reported them here, upon the list of his Crew, as Marines. This is the ship of which Chase himself came some time since and demanded the release— I referred Ayres to the District Attorney at Baltimore, but he said he had a fever, and there was nobody to attend to his business. I suppose he distrusts at least the earnestness of his zeal— Mr George Hay called at the Office. Received a despatch from R. Rush— Earl Bathurst has the temporary management of the Foreign Department after the death of the Marquis of Londonderry— Elijah Mix, a man of too much recent celebrity came for the papers relating to an old claim of compensation for bringing despatches from France during the late War. He had been paid the money, but is now charged with it on the Treasury books, and wants a voucher for his discharge— He appealed to the recollection of the President; but the President had no recollection of it. His papers were returned to him. I called at the Metropolis Bank for an order on Philadelphia, which I obtained. Received a Letter from George M. Dallas of Philadelphia, enclosing a copy of the Oration, which I delivered, on the 17th. of July 1787. at Commencement, upon taking my degree of bachelor of Arts. He says he found it among some of his late father’s papers, but does not know how it came there— Nor do I: but it is the copy which at the request of the late Dr Belknap, I furnished him, for publication, in a Monthly Magazine, then published at Philadelphia; and it was printed in the number for the Month of September 1787— I little thought of ever seeing the manuscript again—but the delivery of that Oration was one of the most memorable Events of
my life— The incidents attending it were of a nature to make and leave a deep impression upon my mind— The appointment to deliver it was itself a high distinction— Yet it was but the second honour of the Class; and he who took the first, the preferred rival, sunk at the age of 35. to be forgotten— I reperused this production now with humiliation; to think how proud of it I was then, and how much I must blush for it now— Attempted this Evening to walk to Coll. Bomford’s to see Mr Erving; but without success.

8. VI:15. Various visitors have this morning Mr N. Berryman, a Solicitor from Virginia for an appointment as Clerk in the Department of State— He is strongly recommended as a very meritorious person; has a family and is in great need. The greatest objection to him is that he has come to reside here solely for the purpose of obtaining this Office— Judge Cranch was also here, and Mr Bailey who came from Force, to ask the loan of Governor Clark’s pamphlet— Bayley afterwards came and introduced Mr Newman, a Cousin of the person with whom I travelled last year, from Providence to New-York— Mr Caldwell came upon the subject of Dr. Ayres’s application against the piratical privateering Slave Smuggler Chase— Coll. Henderson called; just returned from a Northern tour; in which he has been to Quebec and to Boston. At the Office Mr H. Johnson the Senator from Louisiana, came and I read to him the copy received from Mr Rush of the Convention concluded at St. Petersburg last July, by Mr Middleton, and Sir Charles Bagot under the Russian Mediation; to carry into effect the Emperor’s decision upon the contested Construction of the provision in the first Article of the Treaty of Ghent, against the carrying away of Slaves. Johnson made the same objection, against the assumption of an average value for the Slaves as had been taken by Mr Calhoun, who has probably suggested it to him— I wrote part of a Letter to General P. B. Porter, to send him with a Copy of Mitchell’s Map, which he has requested; and this Evening I answered G. M. Dallas’s Letter.

9. VI:15.Joseph Warren, one of the Messengers of my Office, is very dangerously ill with a bilious fever— He is in his vocation one of the most useful and faithful men, I have ever known— Maul an old man, who was formally in the same situation, is a man of different character— One of his Sons is now in the Office, in a place from which I was obliged to remove him. He came this morning to my house to repeat a solicitation, with which he has been long importuning the President and me—for a Pension. He brought me a paper from the Treasury stating that there is there a man, who receives a stipend without performing any services— Superannuated public Officers, are, and will be a burden upon the community. Our Constitutions, and Laws, and principles make no provision for them. Yet the cruelty of casting out upon the world an old man the prime of whose life has been spent in the public service, is too odious, for a temper influenced by feelings of humanity— At the Office, Mr Landon Carter; a young man from Virginia, brother to the widow of the late Mr John Law, brought me a Letter of recommendation from A. Stevenson, the Representative in Congress from the Richmond district. Mr Carter solicits the appointment of Secretary to one of the proposed missions to South-America. He told me that Stevenson had within these few days lost a child; by her Clothes catching fire— I finished the Letter to General Porter to send with the map; and began the examination of J. Mitchell’s Accounts— Evening walk, and Chess.

10. VI:Mr Rice was here, on account of the Loan to the Columbian College; to which he desired further subscriptions— I called at the House of Mr Charles B. King the Painter, but he was not at home. Looked over his new performances; chiefly Portraits of the Indians who were here last Winter. Call at Latruite’s for my Penrings, of which I have had three new ones made— At the Office, I
did not complete the examination of J. Mitchell’s Accounts. Spent the Evening at Dr Thornton’s—where we met Mr Tucker the Treasurer, Mr Petry the Consul General of France, and a Danish Officer from the Island of St. Croix— Dr Thornton is becoming deeply interested in the cause of the Greeks.

11. V: I wrote short Letters to Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison to send with copies of my pamphlet. At the Office, I finished at last the examination of J. Mitchell’s Accounts; and my Report to the President upon them. The example of reopening an Account which has been closed for years at the Treasury for the purpose not of correcting any error, but of making new and discretionary allowances, is so pernicious as a precedent that I have distinctly, and strongly born my testimony against it— On returning home to dinner; Mary Hellen met me at the door— Mrs. Adams, with her brother Thomas B. Johnson, and Mary, had just arrived from Philadelphia, some days sooner than we had expected. They have been absent nearly four Months, and both my wife and her brother have been much benefited in their health by the advice of Dr Physick, under whose care they have been.

12. V:30.Mr L. Rice was here again, upon the Columbian College Loan, to which I further subscribed. Had a visit from General Scott, who told me, he was completing the Settlement of his Accounts at the Treasury; after having met with numerous difficulties. Wrote to R. Walsh junr. an answer to a Letter from him brought me, by Mrs. Adams. Mr John Connell called on me this morning, and dined with us. He had been this morning to Alexandria, and received the Agency of the Marine Insurance Company there for their claims upon the French Government. Connell leaves the City to-morrow Morning to return to Philadelphia, and embarks in a week for France— I told him how earnestly I had recommended him to the President of the Insurance Company, at Alexandria— He said he considered his life as a passage to another, and trusted I should never have occasion to regret the testimonial I had given in his favour. I despatched to the President my Report to him upon John Mitchell’s Accounts. Received a Letter from my father in answer to mine with the Copy of my pamphlet. My last Penring which I took this day at last from Latruite’s, has upon it for a motto FORTIOR ITO. which I have occasion to use as a perpetual admonition— Mr T. B. Johnson and Mrs Smith, dined at Mr Frye’s, & Mr and Mrs Frye spent the Evening with us. Mr Moses Young one of the Clerks in the Department of State, died this Evening— Suddenly; though the state of his health has been for many Months such as led to the expectation of his death, which has been more than once reported as having happened before.

13. VI:15.Mr George S. Bulfinch called this morning, and renewed his application, for an appointment as a Clerk in the Department of State. I gave him little encouragement. Heard Mr Little preach the funeral Sermon upon the Death of Mr John Law. His text was Corinthians 15.26. “The last enemy that shall be destroyed is Death.” This is the Chapter in which the immortality of the Soul, and the Resurrection of the dead, is argued to all the reason, and urged to all the feelings of human Nature with the deepest logic and sublimest eloquence of St. Paul. I am always profoundly affected by the perusal of this chapter. Mr Little’s comment upon it was sensible, and temperate— Death and immortality are topics, never unsuitable, nor exhaustible to a teacher of Religion and Morality. He noticed but slightly Mr Law himself, though in appropriate terms; and he spoke also of the decease of Mr Young. They were both members of this religious Society; and had both taken much interest in its formation, and in the erection of the Church. He gave notice that there would be no afternoon service; but that the funeral of Mr Young would be at four in the afternoon— At the close of the service “Pope’s Dying Christian to his Soul[”] was
sung as an Anthem, with the accompaniment of the organ, and with much effect. This Ode is exquisitely beautiful, though most singularly compounded of five half ludicrous Latin lines, said to have been spoken by the Emperor Adrian, at the Article of Death; of Sappho’s fiery lyric ode; and of that triumphant and transporting Apostrophe of St. Paul in the 55th. verse of this 15th. chapter of Corinthians—“O death where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory?” From these materials, upon a suggestion, and at the request of Steele, Pope wrote this truly seraphic Song; to be set to Music. In comparing it with the lines of Adrian, I see the effect of the Christian doctrines upon the idea of Death. Pope contends that there is nothing trifling, or even gay in the lines of Adrian; but his imagination leads his judgment astray— The heathen philosophers taught that Death was to be met with indifference; and Adrian attempted to carry this doctrine into practice, by joking at his own death, while in its agonies— Yet the thought of what was to become of his Soul, was grave and serious, and his idea of its future State, was that of darkness and gloom. The character of his lines therefore is a singular mixture of levity and sadness, the Spirit of which appears to me to be lost in Pope’s translation of them given in a Letter to Steele— I set down the lines here, with a translation of them as literal, and as much in their Spirit as I can make them.

lg.l: Animula, vagula, blandula, Dear, fluttering, flattering little Soul;
Hospes, comesque corporis, Partner, and inmate of this Clay,
Quae nunc abibis in loca? Ah! whither art thou now to stroll?
Pallidula, rigida, nudula, Cold, shivering, naked little droll;
Nec (ut soles) dabis joca! No more thy wonted jokes, to play!

div.p: Pope insists that the diminutives are epithets not of levity, but of endearment— They are significant of both, and the repetition of them with the rhyme of loca and joca, in Latin verses of that age, decisively mark the merriment of affected indifference. In the process of the correspondence, Steele desired Pope to make an Ode as of a cheerful dying Spirit, that is to say the Emperor Adrian’s Animula vagula, put into two or three Stanzas for Music.— This hint was Pope’s inspiration— He made the cheerful dying Spirit a Christian, and cheerful death then became the moment of triumphant exultation, and the song is as it were the song of an Angel. I was deeply moved at its performance. After church I called to visit General Brown, and his Aids Kirby and Dix; but they were abroad— Attended the funeral of Mr Young; he was buried, at his own request on the side of a hill, in a kitchen garden near his house; though Mr D. Brent, and Mr R. Forrest told me this was contrary to an ordinance of the City Corporation. The service at the grave was performed by Mr Little— I walked part of the way home with Mr Ironside, who told me his wife was just convalescent from a dangerous bilious fever, and rode part with Dr Thornton. Mr G. Hay had called and left a Note of recommendation in favour of his friend Linnaeus Smith for the vacant Clerkship in the Department of State. Mr F. C. Gray called and spent part of the Evening with us. He is here to attend the Session of the Florida Treaty claim Commissioners; which is to commence again this week—

14. V:15. The day was almost swallowed up with applications for the vacant Clerkship. There came in person Mr Berryman, I. K. Hanson, and J. M. Baker— Mr Ogle Tayloe came in his own and his father’s name to recommend a Mr George Forrest, Son of the late General Forrest and a resident of Georgetown. Mr Anderson the Comptroller came to recommend two persons, Mr Berryman, and a Mr Reilly, who has been applying also for a foreign Consulate. Mr Bailey
for G. S. Bulfinch— And at the Office, Mr Berryman again; Mr Maury’sson for himself; Mr Charles Cutts, the Secretary of the Senate, for I scarcely remember whom; Mr Bestor for himself— Mr Calhoun for Mr Van den Burgh, and Mr H. Forrest, for a youth of 17 or 20 named Watson— This person was also warmly urged by a Letter from Mr Wirt the Attorney-General. Mr Cathcart, Mr Ridgley, W. Brown, Hickey, and Richard B. Lee, for Mr Berryman, but also for himself applied by Letters— There is not one of these persons but had a pathetic Story of want to tell for himself or his recommended friend. Some have large and distressed families; and it is distressing to hear their necessities urged, while those of only one can be relieved; and the greatest want, being never in the same person as the greatest qualification— This however is the first principle upon which I am bound to make the appointments, and I determined in this instanced to act upon a second—That is to give the place to a person, not an inhabitant of the district— I therefore fixed upon Francis Linnaeus Smith of Richmond Virginia, recommended by Mr George Hay, as a person qualified for any Service in the Department for which there may be occasion to call—and I wrote to him; offering him the place vacant, being the second Clerkship at the Salary of 800 dollars a year— Having first advanced Fontaine Maury, from a Salary of 1000 to 1400 dollars, which was that of Mr Young, and Thomas L. Thruston, which was the first of the two Clerkships at 800 dollars to that of 1000 dollars, in the place of Mr Maury. Mr Thomas Law paid us a short visit this Evening.

15. VI:Mr George S. Bulfinch came this morning to renew his application for the vacant Clerkship, and learnt with some disappointment that it was filled— He asked if there would be any better prospect for him at the next vacancy— I told him, that with the best disposition to serve him, I could not flatter him with any such encouragement— His qualifications I had no doubt of, but supposing them to be upon an equal footing with those of others, his want of the place could not be so great— He was a young man; without family to support, and already prepared for the practice of the Law. Having thus a Profession, which could provide for him— Others had families in extreme distress, and without other means of subsistence— It was also indispensable to make a portion of the appointments from persons not residing within the district; from which I had hitherto taken more than a due proportion. Those reasons were certainly not satisfactory to him; but he received them with respect, and without any manifestation of improper temper— There came a person of different character and pretensions named Hood, from Loudoun County Virginia, without recommendations; but he said he had come to see if there wasn’t any office in the Department vacant here that he could get. I told him I did not know of any— He said he had heard that Mr Watson who had an office in the Treasury was dead, and he did not know but what he might have his’n. I said he had better enquire at the Treasury Department. Mr George Hay called at the Office to enquire if I had made the appointment, and if I had written to Mr Smith to give him notice of it. I told him I had. He said that would render it unnecessary for him to write to Mr Smith, which he should rather prefer not to do, as if it should be known, that the appointment was obtained at his recommendation, he would be teased with numerous other solicitations— I told him that by the appointment of Mr Smith, I had greatly disappointed another Virginian and highly recommended applicant Mr Berryman— Hay said he did not know him; had never heard of him; and was sure he could not be a man at-all known in Virginia— A young man by the name of Allison, from Alexandria came, and brought Letters from General John Mason, and from the President— The latter was a mere general expression of good will in his favour. He had been at the Office with them once
before. I collected the Letters from the Sardinian Consul Deabbate to answer them, after a long delay. In the Evening I answered a Letter from Mr Joseph Hall of Boston, to send with a copy of my book— Mrs Meigs left here this Evening some papers which were to have been forwarded by him to England for some of his friends in Georgia— It was in obtaining the authentication of them by the British Vice-Consul at Alexandria, that Mr Meigs took the fever of which he died— Mrs Meigs desires me to examine the papers and if they are duly authenticated to forward them.

16. V:30. Wrote to Governor Brooks of Massachusetts and sent him a copy of my book. At the Office I examined again all MrDeabbate’s Letters with a view to answer his demands. I finally dismissed John B. Colvin from the Office of a Clerk in the Department of State— I have come to this Resolution with great reluctance and after indulgence long protracted, and so frequently repeated that I can no longer justify it to myself— His principal vice is habitual and increasing intemperance. He was introduced into the office by Mr Robert Smith, whose confidence in and reliance upon him was rewarded by signal and well known treachery— He had however been continued in the Office, and when sober, was the most active, intelligent, and useful Clerk in it. He had always professed much personal attachment to me since I have been in the Department, and wrote frequently editorial and other Articles in various Newspapers to defend and eulogise me— Very soon after the first of those papers appeared, on hearing of their being attributed to him, I requested him not to continue them with any personal reference to me, though I had no objection, if he saw fit, to defend in that way measures of the administration which might be assailed. But his habits of intoxication, and his absences from the Office, for whole weeks at a time in consequence of them, have been for the last two years growing to such excess, that about six months since, after numerous comings to him, and intreaties from him to be forgiven for the last time, I displaced him as a Clerk with a permanent Salary by the year, and directed that he should be paid by the day, for the days of his actual attendance—Allowing him four dollars a day, which with constant attendance would have been very nearly equivalent to his Salary of 1400 dollars a year— As the Correspondence and the Office details relating to the taking of the Census had been chiefly carried on by him, I gave him the abstract from the returns of the manufactures, required by the Resolution of Congress of the last Session, to be prepared, and earnestly enjoined it upon him to complete it so that it might be printed, and ready to be laid on the table, of the Members on the first day of the next Session— But although paid by the day, pinched by penury, and crippled with debts he has been absent at least half the time, and the Printers of the manufacture-abstract, sent me word last week, that at the rate that copy was furnished them, they could not have the work ready in less than two years. I immediately directed that the work should be transferred to Mr Thruston, and that further special aid should be employed to ensure the completion of the work by the commencement of the Session. Colvin had been several days absent, and it was not known when he would return— But I directed that when he should return he might still be employed in assisting to finish the work— This day I directed that John Martin Baker should be placed as a Clerk with a permanent Salary of 800 dollars from the 13th. instt. the day before the appointment of F. L. Smith— I advanced George Ironside to the Salary of 1000 dollars, and Thomas Thruston to that of 1400 dollars which had been held by Colvin. Baker was many years since a Clerk in the Department; then went to Europe as a Consul and returned as destitute as he went— He has a considerable family, in extreme want. For the last year I
have kept him employed as a supernumerary at 3 dollars a day. He earnestly solicited however the permanent appointment, and I concluded to give it to him— Mr Calhoun called at the Office and enquired if I should attend the Meeting, called for this Evening, by an Advertisement in the Newspapers, which stated that the object of it would be made known at the Meeting itself— Dr Thornton had sent his Messenger to me to enquire if I should attend it, and upon enquiry what the object of it was he said he believed it was something about the Greeks. I told Mr Calhoun I should not attend the Meeting, and thought not much of Dr Thornton’s discretion in calling it. Mr Calhoun said he had also concluded not to attend— I received a despatch from R. Rush with copies of his correspondence, with A. Gallatin upon the new fishery question— Called this Morning upon Mr and Mrs Brown of Louisiana, who have just returned to the City— His brother, Dr. Brown, was with them. Mr and Mrs Frye were here this Evening.

17. VI: Received a Letter from the President; written at Mr Madison’s house at Montpellier, being thus far on his way hither; and giving notice that he expected to arrive here to-morrow or the next day. We received visits from Mr and Mrs Brown of Louisiana, and from Mrs Wirt to Mrs. Adams— Also Mr. and Mrs. Gouverneur, and Mr and Mrs. Bibby. At the Office, Mr Pleasonton the 5th. Auditor came with Mr Warner the Consul at the Havanna— He has been passing the Summer in this Country, and now as the cool Season comes on returns to his Post. Cases of yellow fever occur at the Havanna, at all Seasons of the year, but in the Summer, a Stranger can scarcely escape it— Mr Warner wishes for the opportunity of going thither in one of our Vessels of War, to which I told him I presumed the President would have no objection. But as he only could authorise it, I would mention it to him after his return, which I expected in a day or two— Warner said he would perhaps stay until the Presidents return, and see him himself. I proceeded in the examination of Deabbate’s papers, and began the answer to them. Evening walk; and Chess with W. S. Smith.

18. VI:15. At the Office. Finished the Letter to Mr Deabbate the Sardinian Consul— The Baron Stackelberg, Charge d’Affaires from Sweden, called with a Letter requesting Exequatur’s for two Vice-Consuls—at Philadelphia, and at New-Orleans— He also desired an official Letter to him to be transmitted with them; to serve as a voucher for him— There was an Evening party, a wedding Ball, at Mr Ramsay’s, upon the marriage of Lieutenant Ramsay, his Son, which Mrs Adams, and the family attended, but I did not— Upon the examination of the papers left here by Mrs Meigs, I found there were three material errors in the authentication of one of them, by the British Vice-Consul at Alexandria. Chess with W. S. Smith— The President arrived late, this Evening.

19. VI:Johnson Hellen came from Rockville, to pass a few days with us— I wrote to R. W. Habersham—the District Attorney in Georgia, directing him to obtain the decision of the Circuit Court of the United States, in the case of the Apollon, at their next Session in Georgia; that it may be brought by appeal to the Supreme Court, for their final decision next February. I received Letters from my Sons John and Charles; since their return to Cambridge. Also an anonymous Letter, from Vincennes, Indiana. One from Mr Drayton District judge in South-Carolina, with a copy of the opinion, delivered with his decree in the case of the Spanish privateer Palmyra, or Panchita, captured and brought in to Charleston, by the United States Schooner Grampus, Lieutenant Gregory. The judge decreed the restoration of the Palmyra, to the Spanish Captain, as a regularly commissioned privateer, but gave Lieutenant Gregory a certificate, that he had sufficient cause for the capture, approved his conduct as warranted by his Instructions; and detained for trial the men belonging to
the Palmyra, against whom there was evidence of their having committed piratical depredations upon American vessels— I have in prospect a long correspondence with the Spanish Minister on this subject. Received also despatches from A. Gallatin, and his correspondence with the French Government, concerning the carrying into Execution of the Convention signed here, on the 24th. of June last— There was an Evening party at Mr Brown of Louisiana’s, to which we were all invited, but did not go— I received Mr F. L. Smith’s answer, accepting the appointment to the vacant Clerkship. He will be here in a few days. Mr T. B. Johnson dined at Mr Frye’s.

20. VI:30.Mr Daniel Brent called here this morning. Heard Mr Little in the forenoon, from Ephesians, 4.5. “One Lord, one faith, one baptism.” a Unitarian discourse. After Church I called at Brown’s Hotel, to return the visit of General Jessup, some time since received, but he had removed his lodgings to Mrs Peyton’s— I then called on General Scott at Strother’s— Mrs Scott, her Mother and Sister, Mrs. and Miss Mayo were there— Mrs Scott almost immediately went away, for which the General apologized, saying she was engaged to go with Mrs Brown and pay a visit to Mrs Decatur. In the afternoon, we attended at the Second Presbyterian Church; and heard Mr Breckenridge from Romans 8.1. “There is now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit.” This Mr Breckenridge is the young man, with whom on the 28th: and 29th. of August 1818. I travelled from this place to Philadelphia— A pupil of the Princeton College, and a disciple of Dr Mason at New-York, his doctrines now, are the same with those, which had been well instilled into his mind then— He is not without eloquence, but hardly sustains the promise which his extraordinary sectarian zeal then gave— In the Evening I called at the President’s, and met there a numerous company of miscellaneous visitors— Among whom were Generals Scott and Winder, Mr Yard of Philadelphia, Mr George Graham, Mr Harrison the Auditor, Mr Tench Ringgold the Marshal of the District and several Ladies— Mrs Monroe was unwell, confined to her chamber, but her daughters Mrs. Hay, and Mrs Gouverneur were there, and Mrs Hay’s daughter Hortensia entertained the company with a performance on the Piano. Gouverneur told me, he was going very shortly to New-York to commence the practice of the Law, and said he hoped the Bar there, would be as liberal to him, as the Bar at Boston, had been to my Son George; and would allow him, for two years, that he had been in the office of the Attorney General Mr Wirt— The Weather is at high Summer Heat—Fahrenheit 82.

21. VI:Mrs Meigs some days since gave me a paper stating that J. M. Baker was indebted to her husband’s Estate, 100 dollars, for a note at the Bank of the Metropolis, endorsed by Mr Meigs for him, more than two years since— I shewed this paper to Mr Baker last Saturday, and desired he would settle the affair with Mrs Meigs— He alledged that 44 dollars of it had been paid, by a check for Salary due him as a Clerk in the Land Office, and 30 dollars more, for writing done there, yet uncompensated— This morning I received from him a Letter, enclosing his Affidavit to that effect— But he has no receipt or acknowledgement from Mrs Meigs; nor from her late husband— Baron Stackelberg was at the Office; and mentioned, that he had received two Exequaturs for Swedish Vice Consuls, with a Letter advising him of the transmission to him of two others on a former day. Mr Cowper of Norfolk, came to make some enquiries, concerning a claim of a Mr James Young, for indemnity from the British Government, on Account of five Slaves, belonging to him, taken and condemned as prize of War, at Jamaica, during the late War. I had some correspondence with the British Government on this subject while I was in England, but the particulars of it had passed from my Memory— I promised Mr Cowper, who is attending here upon the Florida Treaty Claim Commission, to examine the papers, and confer with him further hereafter, concerning the claim. Received a Letter from Degrand, an ardent political friend of mine who is continually writing to me Letters; not one in twenty of which I ever answer. I
called at the President’s House, but he was gone out— Home between 4 and 5. O’Clock to an early dinner, to attend the Evening exhibition of Mr Mathews at home— The doors of the Theatre were advertised to be opened at a quarter before six; and the performances to begin at a quarter before seven— We went near half an hour before the doors opened, and were standing, Ladies and Gentlemen, in a crowd waiting for admission to the audience of Mr Mathews— When the door was at length forced open the house was full to overflow, in the space of time necessary for occupying all the Seats. The performances were the Trip to Paris, and the Diligence— Mathews the sole performer, personated in the course of the Evening; ten or twelve characters, male and female; with varieties of voice, and countenance scarcely credible— He has at command a distinct female voice, and the power of ventriloquism, by which he maintains with ease a dialogue of several interlocutors. He has also extraordinary powers of mimicry; a talent perhaps intimately connected with that of varying so much the tones of his voice. His performance was divided into three parts, each occupying upwards of an hour; at the end of the first and second of which he withdrew from the Stage; for a space of 8 or 10 minutes— For the two first parts he had a table before him; at which he stood and discoursed, as if delivering a Lecture— A Chair behind him in which he occasionally seated himself impersonating particular characters, the costumes of which he assumed in the presence of the audience, by a movement, never taking two minutes of time— He thus travestied himself as a French Professor, a German Professor of Craniology, and an old Scotch woman, telling a story how the keys of the kirk were lost. In these parts he imitated the Scotch, the German, and the French pronunciation of English inimitably, and the caricature face of the broad-cheeked, wide-mouthed, heavy-moulded German, then of the long, lank, projected single-toothed frenchman, with a powdered, pomatumed frizzled toupee, and a head sunk into a perpetual shrug of the shoulders, and next of the smooth-tongued, oily mouthed coax-accented Scottish old women, were in the most exact congeniality with their several modes of Speech. In relating the adventures of the passage from Dover to Calais, he introduced a dialogue between several of the supposed characteristic passengers—and described them under the operation of Sea-sickness, with great humour, and yet without indecency— In the third act, instead of his table, he had a Scene as of the door of a Stage-Office, and a French Diligence standing at the back of the Scene. He began with personating an English Boots or Waiter at the Stage-Office; then came in successively in four characters taking Seats in the Diligence, and finally in that of the driver, Monsieur Poudre Meneur, with his blue and red uniform, his long queued powdered hair, his jack-boots, and his wood-thonged whip— His mode of withdrawing from the Stage, to change his character and dress was by getting in to the diligence—and each time when getting in, he gave a disputing dialogue, between the person entering, and those supposed to be already seated in it— One of his personages, was a doll-figure dressed as a boy, shut up in a box from which he occasionally drew him, and held with him a ridiculous dialogue— An old maid brought in another box, in which was supposed to be a lap-dog.— The yelling of which upon being supposed to be pinched, he imitated as exactly as all his varieties of the human voice— The whole entertainment was interspersed with occasional humorous songs—at which during the two first Acts he had the accompaniment of a performer on the Piano; but worse than none; the musician being so rapt in extasy at the exhibition of Mathews himself, as to be never in time for his own. This entertainment was wonderful, and amusing, and continually laughable, and yet passed heavily off— Most of the hearers are weary of it before it is over. Its humour is all light— Its wit flashing away in puns. Its ridicule often resolvable into mere absurdity— It is a picture of Teniers, or of Jan Steen. Imitation
to admire, of that which in nature is only despised— Mrs Adams walked home with me. George sprained his foot there; and Mrs Smith came home quite sick.

22. V:15.Johnson Hellen left us and returned to Rockville— At the Office there came a Mr Pettus to notify his expectation of being appointed to a Clerkship in the Department— On being informed that there was no vacancy, he became very inquisitive, in a tone of easy familiarity which I met with corresponding coldness and reserve. I called at the President’s, with the despatches last received from R. Rush and A. Gallatin— I proposed to the President the appointment of R. Campbell as Consul at Genoa; to which he assented— James Schee, the Consul there against whom there are various complaints, left his Post there nearly a year since, and I know not where he has gone— He left this R. Campbell who is an English merchant there, as his Consular Agent, and there are numerous respectable recommendations in his favour. The appointment would be no object to any Citizen of the United States— Yet a Consul there is now of some importance, to obtain a certain knowledge of facts upon which ultimately to act upon the claims of the Sardinian Consul here, Deabbate. I asked the President what he proposed to do upon the demand of the Danish Minister Pedersen, for the delivery of the fugitive Slave from St. Croix? He said it must be left to the Courts of Justice— The President spoke of beginning the draught of his message for the commencement of the Session of Congress; and desired me to give him a minute of the subjects connected with our foreign Relations, which it would be proper to notice in it— I wrote a despatch to J. Forsyth, to enclose copies of the Letter from the Florida land-title Commissioners, and their Secretary, concerning the Articles of the Province, still detained at the Havanna— Evening walk, and Chess with W. S. Smith.

23. VI:15.Mr Charles Hay called this morning at my house with Mr Francis Linnaeus Smith, whom he introduced to me, and who was afterwards sworn as a Clerk in the Department of State. At the Office, I received a Letter from Cortland Parker, our Consul at Curacao, with an account of an abortive expedition against the Island of Porto-Rico—fitted out chiefly at New-York and Philadelphia, under the command of a German Officer, in the real or pretended service of the Republic of Colombia, and named the Baron Holstein. One of his vessels was under the flag of the Netherlands—but those that went from the United States were engaged upon false pretences, and when the real object was discovered, the Captains refused to proceed— They went into Curacao, where the vessels were seized— They had rendez vous’d at the five-Islands, an appendage to the Swedish Island of St. Bartholomew, whence I had some days since received the first advices of this expedition from Mr Robert Monroe Harrison. Mr Parker has sent me several printed papers, found on board the vessel seized at Curacao— Being a declaration of Independence of the Island offormerly Porto-Rico— A Declaration of the Baron Holstein, as provisional Supreme Chief of the Island—and Proclamations in his name to the Inhabitants of the Island, and to foreign Nations, announcing the Revolution as completed, and promising protection, freedom, and good Government. One of these Proclamations is signed by Baptis Irvine, as Secretary of State— A precious Minister of the Interior! The President gave me several Letters from Lieutenant Ramage, to his commanding Officer Captain James Biddle, with an account of his cruize, in the West Indies— Mrs Adams had an evening party, and dancing, for the Ramsay family, on the marriage of the Lieutenant— Not very numerous. Mrs Minor and her daughter from Natchez were of the Company— And Mrs Orne. The Coll. was indisposed, and did not come— George, whose sprain would not permit him to join in the dance, went to Mathews’s second and last Night at home; in this City.

24. VI:30.Mrs Adams, and her brother T. B. Johnson, went and dined with their Sister, Mrs Hellen, at Alexandria. They returned home before our dining time. Mr Canning called at the Office, having the
night before last returned from his Summer excursion. He has been to Quebec, Montreal, and Boston. He brought with him a Letter from the King of Great-Britain, addressed to the United States of America; which he said being rather of an old date, he would request me to take charge of, to be delivered to the President, rather than ask a special Audience for the purpose. It was merely a notification of the birth of a daughter to the Duke of Cambridge at Hanover— We had also a couple of hours of desultory conversation upon various political topics, as well of general interest, as of particular concernment between the two Nations at this time— He spoke first of the measures recently adopted in England, and here, for opening the commercial intercourse between this Country, and the British Colonies in America. He observed that complaint had been made to him that by a Circular Letter from the Comptroller of the Treasury to the Collectors of the Customs, explanatory of the President’s Proclamation of 24. August last, the foreign tonnage, and discriminating duties, were levied upon British vessels from the American Colonies, and upon Articles imported in them— He said this was not only short of reciprocity to the provisions of the Act of Parliament opening the Colonial Ports to our Vessels, but laid the British Navigation under such disadvantages, as would make it impossible for them to pursue the trade in competition with ours— There was another restriction too upon British Vessels from the Colonies which had no counterpart in the Act of Parliament— Those from the West-Indies being allowed to import only British West-Indian Articles, and those from North-America only Articles of their own growth or produce. As the object on both sides was to open the intercourse on terms of reciprocity, and as these regulations were so incompatible with it, he hoped we would remove them immediately; and he remarked that the Act of Parliament authorised the king in Council to withhold the privileges of the intercourse from Nations which should not grant the same privileges to British Vessels in return. I told him we were aware of that; and that the Proclamation had gone as far as the President was authorized by the Act of Congress of the last Session to go, in meeting this overture— We had even given a very enlarged Construction to the words of the Act, by admitting Vessels from North-American Ports under an authority to admit vessels from the West-Indies— But the Act of Parliament, did not grant to our Vessels the advantages secured to them in the European British Ports, by the Convention of 3. July 1815— It admitted them only by a voyage, direct from the United States, allowed them to return only to the United States— It admitted only certain enumerated Articles, and charged them with duties, almost equivalent to prohibition; while it excluded the most important articles of our exports suited to the Colonial Markets. Besides which our vessels which had entered their Ports in the West-Indies under the Act of Parliament had been subjected to an export duty, levied by the Colonial authority, distinct from the duties levied by the Act of Parliament; and were otherwise so shackled and trammelled that our own Merchants thought it impossible for them, to pursue the trade in competition with the British, and we had received remonstrances against opening the Ports at-all, subject to the Conditions required under this Act of Parliament. I mentioned to him the Letters I had received from Mr Hollingsworth, the Consul at St. Eustatius with the enclosed opinion of the Attorney General of St. Kitts; and promised to have them looked up and to shew them to him— I told him also that I had written to Mr Rush, immediately after the proclamation issued, mentioning the continued disposition of this Government to concur with the British, in any measures necessary for setting this intercourse upon principles of reciprocity, and our belief that some further understanding between the two Governments concerning it would be advisable. The next subject upon which he touched was the disagreeing Reports of the Commissioners
under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent. He said that before he left the City last Summer he had written to his Government, for Instructions, in reference to what had passed between us: he had not yet received his answer, and perhaps it might be now further delayed, by the changes in the British Ministry, consequent upon the death of the Marquis of Londonderry— I asked him if Mr. George Canning would accept of the Office of Secretary for the foreign Department in preference to that of Governor General of India, to which he had already been appointed— He thought he would— The place in India is more lucrative—that in England more brilliant, and more deeply responsible— I said that from what I had observed of Mr Canning’s character, I believed that upon a question resolvable only by that alternative, he would without hesitation choose the place at home; but I had supposed other considerations would be involved in the formation of his decision. Mr Canning had been more than once distinguished in his relations with the Cabinet, by adherence to his personal Independence, more than to his place. He was supposed to entertain opinions upon important objects of national policy, clashing with those of other leading members of the Cabinet. Whether they could be reconciled, or whether they could be disposed of so that an Administration could move in the harmony necessary for successful operation under them, was an enquiry which I should expect would give more cause for hesitation to Mr Canning, than a mere question between money and glory. It was expected if Mr Canning should come in to the foreign Department, that the foreign Policy of Great Britain, would undergo some modification— That the proceedings of the Congress at Vienna, would be affected by it— He said the Duke of Wellington was going to the Congress of Vienna; but the Duke of Wellington goes only to execute instructions, and the system, must go from the foreign Department— Assenting to this remark he passed to the subject of the Slave-trade, and enquired if we were prepared to resume that discussion— I said we were prepared to receive and consider any further observations which he might be disposed to offer concerning it— He said that in his late tour, he had become satisfied, that our compliance with the proposal of admitting mutual search, depended personally and exclusively upon me. I assured him he had been misinformed, as he might hereafter have occasion to know— This topic was not further pressed and he withdrew— Evening walk, and Chess with W. S. Smith.

25. VI:30. At the Office, I had a visit from Edward Coles, Governor elect of the State of Illinois. He told me that both the Senators from that State, Thomas and Edwards though in violent opposition to each other had been equally opposed to him— By their mode of Election the person having the highest number of votes succeeds, and Coles is chosen by 2800 out of 8500 votes. I wrote to John B. Colvin finally dismissing him from the Department of State— When he recovered last week from his carousal, sufficiently to return to the Office, he found the work of the digest of manufacturing returns in the hands of Mr Thruston, to whom I had directed that it should be transferred— But as a last indulgence to Colvin, I had also ordered that he might still be employed by the day when he would attend, to assist in completing the digest. When he came back Mr Thruston gave him this information accordingly. He then wrote me a Letter, stating that he could get the work ready for the commencement of the Session of Congress; (which he well knew he could not) but that he was unwilling to be employed upon it as an assistant— I therefore now wrote him that if it did not suit his inclination or his convenience to be thus employed, I wished him success and prosperity in any occupation that he might find elsewhere— He has no resource but that of lampooning in a Newspaper to which he will of course resort. He has talents of a high order; but degraded by the grovelling vices of sensuality, and inflated by Vanity and Self-sufficiency, they form a compound of servile fawning, with bloated insolence, of transparent hypocrisy, and self betraying-Treachery, which presents one of the most melancholy contemplations of human Nature— At once exalted and debased— Commercing with the Skies, by the faculties of the Mind— Wallowing in pollution, by the depravities of the heart. I receive a Note from
the President, directing a Meeting of the Members of the Administration, at Noon to-morrow. As I left my Office to return home for dinner I met T. B. Johnson who walked with me. We met and spoke to Mr Josiah Stoddart Johnston, the member of the House of Representatives from Louisiana— Solitary Evening walk, and Chess with W. S. Smith.

26. V:30. Cabinet Meeting at the President’s at Noon— Present, Mr Calhoun and Mr Wirt. The subject for Consideration, was the Instructions to be given to Captain Biddle, who is going to cruize in the West-India Seas— Letters from Captains Spence, Cassin and Renshaw, who have been recently cruizing there, to the Secretary of the Navy were read. The instructions heretofore given to our naval officers, under the recent Slave-trade and Piracy acts were brought in by Mr Homans, the Chief Clerk of the Navy Department— From the annoyance to our commerce of late by Pirates of various descriptions, and from the capture of several of them, with real or colourable Spanish Commissions, questions have arisen how far, the Instructions to Biddle should be modified; how far privateering Commissions from Porto-Rico may be respected; whether a blockade of all the Ports of Terra-firma, by more declarations of Spanish Officers at Porto-Cavello should be recognized, and whether Biddle should be authorized to convey our Merchant vessels to any of those Ports. The Spanish Privateers from Porto-Rico, began by capturing all vessels bound to or from any of the Ports in Terra-firma, on the double pretence of a blockade of the whole Coast, declared by Spanish Officers themselves besieged in the only Port possessed by them, and having only one old Frigate, and two small vessels to support it, and of the old Spanish exclusion of all foreign vessels from the Ports of their Colonies—and in one case when the judge at Porto-Rico, decreed the restoration of a vessel carried in there, the Captain of the Privateer told him in open Court, that if his prize was thus released, he would follow her out of Port, take her again, and carry her in to Porto Cavello— The Palmyra some days before she was taken by the Grampus, had made an attempt and pretension to examine and search an American Vessel under her convoy. The President now inclined to give Instructions to Biddle to remonstrate to the Governor of Porto Rico, and to the Commanders of any Spanish armed Vessels with whom he may fall in, against the Blockade, and to declare that it cannot be acknowledged by the United States as valid, but to avoid any positive act of force against it. But Spence and Renshaw both have remonstrated against the Blockade to the Governor of Porto-Rico, who answered them that he would report their remonstrances to the Spanish Governments but that it had been declared by the commanding Officers in Terra-firma, over whose acts he had no controul; nor could he revoke them— I thought Biddle should be instructed to go in to Porto Cavello itself, and there declare to the Spanish Commanders themselves that the United States would not recognize their paper Blockades, and also to convoy American vessels to or from any Port, not actually invested: and in no case whatever to permit the search or boarding of any vessel under his Convoy. Calhoun was at first startled at this. He thought that to resist the search would be war, and doubted the Power of the Executive to give such instructions— I said it was the old question of Sterrett and the Enterprize, who after fighting and compelling to surrender, the Tripolitan Cruizer let her go, because he thought he could not bring her in as prize— To authorize force in self-defence, I believed the authority of the Executive under our Constitution, to be entirely competent, and if a naval Officer could be authorised to convoy at-all, he must be authorised to defend the convoyed vessel as he would his own, against force. Calhoun asked it we could authorise the merchant vessel itself to resist the belligerent right of search— I said no— And that the British claimed the right of searching convoyed vessels— But that we had never admitted that right; and that the opposite principle was that of the armed Neutrality— They maintained, that a Convoy was a pledge on
the part of the convoying Nation that the convoyed vessel has no Articles of contraband on board, and is not going to a blockaded Port; and the word of honour of the commander of the convoy to that effect must be given— But I added, if we could instruct our officer to give convoy at-all, we cannot allow him to submit to the search by foreigners of a vessel under his charge; for it is placing our officer and the Nation itself in an attitude of inferiority and humiliation— The President agreed with this opinion, and Mr Calhoun declared his acquiescence in it. And it was determined that the Instructions to Biddle should be drawn accordingly— Mr Calhoun asked me if Mr Early of Georgia, had called upon me— He had not— He had upon Calhoun, and upon the President— His object was to represent that John H. Morel, the Marshal for the District of Georgia, was now accumulating a fortune of at least 30 000 dollars a year; by working a number of African negroes, who are in his possession as Marshal of the District, while at the same time he is making the most enormous charges against the Public, for the maintenance of the very same negroes— That he makes it his open boast, that he holds the Office of Marshal for no other purpose, and that he intends to swamp the Negroes, that is, to work them to death, before they shall be finally adjudicated, out of his possession. Mr Early adds that his cruelty to Negroes is universally notorious, and that it is equally well known, that he did commit the murder of the black man, for which he was tried and acquitted— The principle witnesses against him were spirited away— Early declares himself to be of the same political party as Mr Morel, (Crawford’s) but is so horror-struck at the character and conduct of the man, that he feels it to be his duty to denounce him— Yet he does not incline to support his charges with his name, Morel being a man of such desperation that every body fears him— Early wished that the District Attorney and Judge might be authorised to investigate the circumstances of the Custody of these Negroes, but I thought it very doubtful whether that would avail— The District Attorney had shewn in the case of the “Bullock’s”, that he was not the man to grapple with deep and deadly villainy, supported by wealth and standing in Society— The President inclined to send a person to Savannah specially charged with the investigation. Mr Calhoun intimated the propriety of dismissing Morel immediately from Office; but the President said that could not be done while there was no avowed accuser against him— I received last year two anonymous Letters, charging him with the murder of the Negro; but Mr Tattnall and Mr Cuthbert, both highly respectable members of the Georgia Delegation in Congress took so deep an interest in his favour, that he was reappointed to the Marshal’s Office, though I did believe that the ineffaceable stain of blood was upon his hands— The President determined for the present only to direct that the accounts of Morel for keeping the Negroes, should not be paid at the Navy Department, and that further examination should be made hereafter— Young Laborie came and spent an hour with me this Evening— Mrs Adams was at Mr Frye’s and had dined there— Their Child is very ill.

27. VI: Rain the whole day. In the morning, I heard Mr Little, from Galatians 6.14.15. “But God forbid that I should glory, save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom the world is crucified unto me, and I unto the world— For in Christ Jesus, neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision, but a new creature.” From the text Mr Little made a Sermon against the Calvinistic doctrine of the Atonement. He announced also the purpose of administering the communion, as soon as a sufficient number of communicants should appear to partake of it— I went to attend the afternoon service, but it was prevented by the weather. I received Letters from J. B. Prevost in Chili, from the Vice Consul at Rio de Janeiro, Sartoris; and from Mr Burckle at Philadelphia, asking
for a Passport to go to Europe— He says that he has succeeded in part, with his projected loan, and expects to succeed for the remainder in Europe. Mr Edward Coles dined and passed the Evening with us— He is here to resign his office and settle his Accounts, as Receiver of Public Monies, in a Land-Office in Illinois.

28. V:30. Visit of two hours at the Office from Mr Canning. He resumed the Subject of the West India trade, and urged again for the admission of British vessels from the Colonial Ports, upon the same terms with regard to duties as our own. I repeated to him that the President could do nothing further before the Meeting of Congress. He said he was afraid he should be obliged then to trouble me with a long note upon the subject. I told him I should then of course lay it before the President, by whom it would be deliberately considered. He took from his Pocket immediately and gave me his Note, and with it an extract of a Letter from Barbadoes, mentioning that orders had been received there from London to admit American Vessels, upon payment of the same fees, as are paid by British Vessels; and expressing some misgivings how it would all operate, and a sort of imperious assurance that their Vessels, must of course be admitted into our Ports, upon the same terms as our own— I observed that this should be more than was even implied in the Letter, as being extended to us, for that spoke only of the same fees, which included neither duties, nor Port-charges by the necessary import of the term— But that a different Construction appeared to have been given to the Act of Parliament in other Islands, and I looked up and read to him the Letter from Mr Hollingsworth, and the opinion enclosed in it of the King’s Attorney, Woodley, at St. Kitts— I then asked how it would be possible for our vessels to stand any competition in the trade, with theirs, while theirs should enjoy here every advantage and exemption of our own, Liberty to import from all of their Ports West-India, North-American, or British European Articles indiscriminately, admitted upon credit for the duties, and subject neither to duty nor restriction upon exportation, while ours were restricted to direct voyage, both to and from their Ports and the United States, limited to a specific list of enumerated Articles of importation, all heavily laden with duties, and pinioned with an export bond, and ransomed with an export-duty of 4 1/2 or 5 per Cent. How was it possible for us to throw wide open all the Gates, while they only half-opened one door? He said the expression was rather strong. But that the common object of the Act of Parliament and of the Act of Congress was to open the intercourse upon liberal terms of reciprocity— That the Act of Congress in its Spirit contemplated a correspondent indulgence to every such provision in the Act of Parliament— Whether yet further accommodations to the trade could be hereafter granted might be a subject of negotiation, or of further Legislation; but in the meantime, it appeared consonant to our own interest to yield specific counterpart for every favour extended to our vessels by the Act of Parliament, and as that subjected neither our vessels, nor the merchanize imported in them, to any duties, to which British vessels, and the same articles imported in them are not also liable. In the Spirit of Both Acts, British vessels and their importations here are fairly entitled to the same advantages as our own; and if not now granted, would give them hereafter a fair claim for indemnity to the full extent in which they may be withheld. I said that was what we could not admit— The Act of Parliament was an Act of voluntary Legislation on the part of Great-Britain, passed with reference to her own interest, and requiring nothing of us as obligatory in return— We were indeed disposed to meet it, in a Spirit of liberality, and even to go further; but we must judge of its liberality to us, from the practical result of its operation, and not from the specific purport of its provisions. For real reciprocity and equal competition we
we are prepared; but not for dispositions reciprocal by the Letter, and one sided in their effect.— He said that the restriction of importations to West-Indian Articles from the West-Indies and to North-American Articles from North-America had no counterpart in the British Act of Parliament— The Act of Parliament admitted vessels from all parts of the United States with productions of any part— A vessel from Boston for example, could carry the produce of Virginia or of Louisiana and vice-versa— But the Proclamation considered the British Colonies in the West-Indies as one Country, and the British Colonies in North-America as another— The British Government, might as well discriminate between the Northern and the Southern State— The British Act considered all the Countries under the same Government as one— We divided the Colonies into two Classes, and refused to receive the productions of one Class from the Ports of the other— I replied that this restriction though not identical as a specific counterpart to theirs was corresponding to it as to the effect— They admitted us only to enumerated Ports— They admitted only enumerated articles— They loaded those Articles with almost prohibitory duties, and excluded from them our principal Articles of trade adapted to the market. Our counter restriction is not by enumeration either of Articles or of places, but by classification of both— The British Colonies in the West-Indies, and in North-America, are to all purposes of commerce and Navigation Countries as different from each other as Portugal and Sweden— They are under a government totally different in relation to our intercourse with them from that of Great Britain.
